102.title: Network Kernel Extensions
102.description:
Learn about the new and improved Network Kernel Programming Interfaces for developing Network Kernel Extensions (NKEs). This session walks through the various types of NKEs using concrete examples.

Presenter: Joshua Graessley, Core OS Networking

103.title: Mac OS X Kernel Programming
103.description:
The Mac OS X Kernel changed significantly to provide better SMP performance, fine-grained locking, and support for 64-bit apps. This session describes changes that motivated the creation of Kernel Programming Interfaces (KPIs), their effects on some kernel programming techniques, and the introduction of KPIs into the kernel.

Presenters:
- Simon Patience, Director of Engineering
- Dean Reece, I/O Kit Manager

104.title: Core Networking Update
104.description:
Mac OS X offers a rich set of programming interfaces for networking, combining built-in support for industry standard media types, protocols and services with innovative services from Apple. This session provides an overview of new networking capabilities and APIs available in Mac OS X and demonstrates how they can be used to accomplish a wide range of networking tasks.

Presenter: Laurent Dumont, Sr. Software Engineer

105.title: Getting to the Core of Mac OS X with Darwin
105.description:
Apple makes available the source code to many components of Mac OS X, including its Unix-based core, Darwin. This session introduces you to the tools and techniques for building Darwin directly from the source. It also provides a brief update on, and pointers to, other open source technologies covered at the conference.

Presenter: Kevin Van Vechten, Open Source Software Engineer

106.title: Service Management in Mac OS X
106.description:
If you develop StartupItems or background processes (daemons), this session describes the best techniques for developing these services for today and the future.

Presenter: Dave Zarzycki, Sr. Software Engineer

107.title: Porting Unix Applications to Mac OS X
107.description:
Porting Linux and Unix applications to Mac OS X is easy. This session discusses tools and APIs designed to make it even easier. We cover all the basic concepts in bringing Unix applications to Mac OS X.

Presenters:
- Dave Zarzycki, Sr. Software Engineer
- Waqar Malik, DTS Engineer

108.title: File System Best Practices for Application Developers
108.description:
Learn how to structure your I/O to improve your application's performance. We discuss direct and async I/O, when using mmap is appropriate, as well as upcoming enhancements to the file system.

Presenter: Patrick Dirks, Core OS File Systems Tech Lead

200.title: Core Audio in Depth
200.description:
Mac OS X features a state-of-the-art audio engine in Core Audio, enabling the most powerful music and audio applications available today. Learn how you can harness these capabilities for your own development. This session brings you up to speed on the latest innovations including OpenAL for gaming audio, as well as cover basics such as codecs, APIs, audio file formats, and more.

Presenters:
- James McCartney, Digital Audio Plumber
- Doug Wyatt, Core Audio/MIDI Plumber
- William Stewart, Digital Audio Plumber

201.title: Introducing Core Image
201.description:
Core Image is Mac OS X's new image processing architecture that takes full advantage of the processing power available in the latest GPUs. Core Image provides a wide spectrum of built-in filters that provide high performance image processing operations such as blurs, distortions, transition effects, and color adjustments. View this session and learn about the latest revolution in image processing.

Presenters:
- Ralph Brunner, Mineralogist, Encoded in YCbCr
- Mark Zimmer, Eye Candymaker, Performed in front of a live audience
- Frank Döepke, Packaging Expert, Store under cool, dry conditions

202.title: Introducing PDFKit
202.description:
PDFKit is a powerful set of Cocoa classes that allows you to incorporate a rich PDF viewing experience in your application. PDFKit easily handles all the details relating to PDF display, navigation, selection, and searching. PDFKit also supports a variety of ways to customize your application's interaction with PDF documents. View this session to learn about leveraging the power of PDF in your application.

Presenter: John Calhoun, Software Engineer

203.title: New Developments in Quartz 2D
203.description:
Quartz 2D is the powerful 2D graphics engine in Mac OS X, with advanced features such as transparency, anti-aliasing, and PDF support. Exciting new developments in Quartz 2D are discussed in this session along with a focus on best practices you should follow to get the most out of Quartz 2D. This session is a must see for all WWDC attendees who use 2D graphics in their applications.

Presenters:
- Derek B Clegg, Quartz Overlord
- John Burkey, Quartz Accelerator

204.title: Graphics and Media State of the Union
204.description: Mac OS X contains an industry-leading array of 2D, 3D and multimedia technologies that will make your application excel. This session provides in-depth information on Mac OS X's graphics and audio architecture. This session is the perfect kickoff for developers attending sessions in the Graphics and Media track.

205.title: Audio Hardware and MIDI
205.description:
This session provides both device and application developers with an overview of Mac OS X audio and MIDI device support. Emphasis is placed on audio transmission over high-speed serial interfaces such as USB and FireWire, along with techniques for extending the functionality provided by the Apple drivers for standardized interfaces.

Presenter:
- Doug Wyatt, Core Audio/MIDI Plumber
- Jeff Moore, Software Engineer, Core Audio
- Nick Thompson, Engineering Manager, CPU Audio Software
- James Lewis, President, Oxford Semiconductor Inc.
- Yoram Solomon, General Manager, Consumer Electronics Connectivity Business Unit, Connectivity Solutions Group, Texas Instruments

207.title: High Dynamic Range Imaging with Image IO
207.description:
Image IO is Mac OS X's unified architecture for opening and saving popular image file formats. View this session to learn how the Image Quartz-friendly API simplifies working with TIFF, PNG, JPEG, and JPEG-2000. This is a must-see session for developers working in digital video, cinema, and photography.

Presenters:
- David Hayward, Graphics Engineer
- Luke Wallis, ColorSync Engineer
- Gabriel Marcu, Senior Scientist

208.title: QuickTime API Update
208.description:
This session provides an overview of the new developments in QuickTime APIs. Developers viewing this session will learn how to take advantage of these new directions in their own applications

Presenter: Kevin Calhoun, Software Engineer

209.title: Mac OS X OpenGL in Depth
209.description:
Learn the techniques and features that allow you to take full advantage of the high-performance integrated graphics pipeline in Mac OS X. This session focuses on Mac OS X's OpenGL architecture, platform-specific features, and advanced capabilities. A must for any developer new to Mac OS X or OpenGL and for those who want to stay up-to-date with the latest OS-level features.

Presenter: Geoff Stahl, OpenGL Engineer

210.title: OpenGL Optimization: Best Practices
210.description:
This session focuses on techniques to optimize your application's use of OpenGL and 3D graphics hardware. A variety of optimization strategies, such as display list and vertex array optimizations, are discussed. A great session for all OpenGL developers covering the latest in high-performance graphics.

Presenter: John Stauffer, OpenGL Engineering Manager

211.title: OpenGL Optimization: Live
211.description:
The best in class suite of OpenGL tools in Mac OS X helps take your application's graphics to the next performance level. In this session, Apple's OpenGL experts work live on stage to debug OpenGL client applications and to work through real-world optimization scenarios. This session elaborates on topics discussed in other OpenGL optimization sessions. A must-see session for all OpenGL developers.

Presenters: Dave Springer, Chris Niederauer, Excellent Graphics Software Engineers

212.title: Mac OS X Printing
212.description:
The Mac OS X printing system is the integration point for many key technologies: Quartz, ColorSync, Rendezvous, and more. This session covers how these technologies combine to make a powerful and flexible printing architecture. Areas to be discussed include printing best practices, CUPS printer driver development, Cocoa PDEs, and PDF workflow.

Presenters:
- Paul Danbold, Imaging Technologies Evangelist, Printing Stooge
- Richard Blanchard, Slave Driver

Demo: Alan ‘Demo Meister’ Beck

213.title: QuickTime Audio Update
213.description:
This session discusses the latest advances in QuickTime's audio architecture. Learn techniques and best practices for incorporating audio in your applications with QuickTime.

Presenters:
- Greg Chapman, QuickTime Audio Foundation
- Brad Ford, QuickTime Engineering

214.title: Programming QuickTime with Cocoa
214.description:
Learn of the capabilities that make it simple and natural to work with QuickTime in the Cocoa environment. If you use QuickTime in your Cocoa applications or would like to enhance your products with QuickTime's multimedia capabilities, view this session to learn all about the new Cocoa developments from the QuickTime engineering team.

Presenters:
- Ian Ritchie, Manager QuickTime Engineering
- Tim Monroe, QuickTime Cocoa Lead Engineer
- Tom Maremaa, Tech Pubs
- Kevin Calhoun, Software Engineer
- Adrian Baerlocher, QuickTime Engineer

Demo:
- Michael B. Johnson, PhD, MPG Lead, Pixar Animation Studios

215.title: New Directions for QuickTime Performance
215.description:
Mac OS X Tiger features exciting media services that leverage the GPU for real-time performance and high-quality effects. See how QuickTime uses these services to provide high performance processing throughout the video pipeline, and how you can use these capabilities to provide features such as integrating video into OpenGL scenes, and application of real time video effects.

Presenters:
- Tim Cherna, Engineering Manager, QuickTime Video Foundation
- Sean Gies, QuickTime Video Engineer
- Ken Dyke, Sr. Mad Scientist, Quartz Effects
- Frank Döpke, Software Engineer, Quartz Effects

Demo: Jim Batson

216.title: Alternative Programming Languages for QuickTime
216.description:
Applications and in-house tools that use QuickTime can be developed using a wide variety of tools and languages, including C; Cocoa and Power Plant; REALbasic, Visual Basic, Revolution, and AppleScript Studio; and even scripting languages like tcl and Perl. This session surveys these and other alternatives, illustrates how to use a few of them, and assesses their capabilities.

Presenters:
- Tim Monroe, Apple Computer
- John Cromie, Skylark Associates

217.title: Next-generation Video Formats in QuickTime
217.description:
Modern codecs demand a more complex infrastructure in order to support advanced encoding techniques. Find out what kind of changes are occurring in QuickTime movies and how your applications and video codecs can take advantage of these new techniques.

Presenters:
- Tim Cherna, Engineering Manager, QuickTime Video Foundation
- Thomas Pun, Software Engineer, Video Codec Team
- anne jones, Senior Software Engineer, QuickTime
- Sam Bushell, Technical Lead, Image Compression Manager

218.title: Java 2D and 3D Graphics on Mac OS X
218.description:
This session discusses the drawing capabilities of Java in Mac OS X, and offers techniques for getting the most out of anti-aliased Quartz-based Java2D graphics, the Java3D API for rendering 3D universes, the Java Advanced Imaging API for sophisticated image manipulation, and the high performance OpenGL-based binding available through jogl.

Presenters:
- Matt Drance, Apple Java DTS
- Caroline Clabaugh, Java Classes Engineer
- Ken Russell, Sun Microsystems

219.title: Transitioning to Quartz 2D
219.description:
As Quartz 2D, the 2D graphics engine in Mac OS X continues to evolve, it moves further ahead of QuickDraw. Learn how to transition applications from QuickDraw to Quartz 2D to take advantage of new features and capabilities. This session outlines a Quartz 2D transition plan for QuickDraw developers and explores solutions to common problems they might encounter.

Presenters:
- Haroon Sheikh, Quartz Engineering Manager
- Joseph Maurer, QuickDraw Bavarian

220.title: Introduction to the OpenGL Shading Language
220.description:
Mac OS X OpenGL will support the OpenGL Shading Language (GLSL), allowing creation of vertex and pixel shaders using a high-level C-like language. View this session to learn details on GLSL and its implementation within Mac OS X. This session is ideal for developers of games, scientific visualization applications, and others looking to exploring the power of the GPU.

Presenter: James A. McCombe, 3D Graphics Engineer

221.title: Using Digital Imaging Devices in Your Application
221.description:
The Image Capture Framework is evolving to support a wide range of imaging devices and communication protocols. View this session to hear about the latest Image Capture-related developments and to learn how to harness the power of digital imaging devices in your application.

Presenter: Werner Neubrand

222.title: Discovering Quartz Composer
222.description:
Quartz Composer is a development tool provided with Mac OS X v10.4 for processing and rendering graphical data. It allows developers to use Quartz 2D, Core Image, Core Video, OpenGL, and QuickTime technologies through a visual programming environment. Developers can use Quartz Composer as an exploratory tool to learn the tasks each visual technology performs without learning the API for that technology.

Presenter: Pierre-Olivier Latour, Quartz Composer Architect

223.title: Audio Unit Development and Hosting
223.description:
Mac OS X features a plug-in architecture for DSP effects and virtual instruments, called Audio Units. This session takes an in-depth look at developing Audio Units, and provides best practices that all host applications should follow. Also learn about the Audio Unit logo licensing program designed to let your customers know that your product includes or supports Audio Units.

Presenter: William Stewart, Digital Audio Plumber

300.title: Development Technologies Overview
300.description:
With rapid development technologies, a groundbreaking user interface, and powerful features like built-in performance optimization tools, Xcode can help you work faster and smarter. View this session to learn how using Xcode Tools can increase your productivity and help you deliver outstanding Mac OS X products.

Presenters:
- Ted Goldstein, VP Development Technologies
- Rich Siegel, Bare Bones Software
- Gavriel State, Co-CEO & CTO, TransGaming
- Matt Firlik and Chris Espinosa, Xcode Team Managers
- Steve Peters, Apple Computer 64-bit Team
- Nathan Slingerland and Sanjay Patel, Architecture and Performance Group
- Todd Fernandez and Tim Bumgarner, From the Automator Team

301.title: Automated Testing on Mac OS X
301.description:
Using practical examples, this session teaches you how adding an AppleScript interface to your application can provide an efficient and powerful way to create thorough automated testing. Real-world techniques are highlighted that you can immediately begin to incorporate into your work. This is an intermediate-level session.

Presenters:
- John Comiskey, Humble Coder
- Doug Simons, Redstone Software

Demo: Jonathan Gillaspie, Redstone Software

302.title: Objective-C++: Language and Runtime Integration
302.description:
Objective-C++ combines the dynamic object model of Objective-C with the rich data abstraction facilities of C++ to create the ultimate power tool for many programming tasks. We explore the runtime model provided by Objective-C and then discuss Objective-C++ design goals and philosophy, and Xcode integration and support. We also cover issues in performance and compatibility. This session uses real-world programming examples and covers recent language additions to simplify C++ STL usage. This is an introductory to intermediate-level session.

Presenter: Steve Naroff, Senior Technical Director, Tools

303.title: Developing for Automator
303.description:
Mac OS X Tiger includes Automator, a powerful new application that lets users automate repetitive tasks without having to write scripts.

Presenters:
- Todd Fernandez, Automator Engineering Manager
- Tim Bumgarner, Sr. Engineer
- Eric Peyton, Sr. Engineer

304.title: Introduction to Xcode
304.description:
In this session, you'll get an overview of the latest release of the Xcode development tools and learn all about the new features and updates. This session includes a walkthrough of the IDE, detailing features for editing, building, and debugging your projects, as well as other aspects of the development cycle. We also talk about the future of Xcode tools. This is an introductory to intermediate-level session.

Presenter: Matthew Firlik, Engineering Manager, Xcode

305.title: Using AppleScript Studio
305.description:
Get an in-depth look at advanced AppleScript Studio features as we present practical applications of this sophisticated development technology. Discover how AppleScript Studio enables rapid development of full featured Mac OS X applications. This is an intermediate-level session.

Presenter: Tim Bumgarner, Sr. AppleScript Engineer
Demo: John Coelho, AppleScript Studio QA Engineer

306.title: Importing Development Projects into Xcode
306.description:
We demonstrate how to use Xcode to further develop an existing project from other development environments. Included are techniques on how to import open source projects and C/C++ projects from CodeWarrior, as well as how to configure imported projects. Debugging project configurations are also featured. This is an intermediate-level session.

Presenter: Scott Tooker, Xcode Engineer

307.title: Maximizing Performance: Got Shark?
307.description:
Want the best performance out of your Mac OS X application? This session is all about performance: How to think about it, measure it, and improve it. We go in depth on how developers can use Shark to identify performance problems related to memory bandwidth and algorithmic issues, and describe new features that make Shark an even more powerful performance tool.

Presenters: Nathan Slingerland and Sanjay Patel, Architecture and Performance Group

308.title: Increasing Productivity Using Xcode Part I
308.description:
This session explores a range of intermediate and advanced topics to show you how the Xcode integrated development environment can work best for you. We examine project configuration, build styles, and build system optimizations. We also cover the use of integrated source code management and workflow inside of Xcode, as well as building from the command line.

Presenters:
- Steve Lewallen, Xcode Engineer
- Dave Ewing, Xcode Engineer
- Matt Morse, Xcode Engineer

309.title: Increasing Productivity Using Xcode Part II
309.description:
View this session to learn how to organize your configuration for large project development, use distributed builds, and configure for workgroups. Topics include the use of scripting to drive the Xcode environment through repetitive tasks, as well as maintaining projects that require sharing source code with Project Builder and make-based development.

Presenter: Anders Bertelrud, Lead Engineer—Xcode

311.title: Using Performance Analysis Tools for Mac OS X
311.description:
Xcode includes a broad suite of tools for profiling and analyzing applications. This session gives an overview of the performance tools that ship with Xcode, including Shark, Spin Control, MallocDebug and others. We explain how developers can use these powerful tools to identify and fix performance issues. Introductory to intermediate-level session.

Presenters:
- Dave Payne, Performance Tools Engineer
- Christy Warren, Tiger Responsiveness Lead Engineer

313.title: Modeling/Design in Xcode
313.description:
Learn about Xcode's new design tools for object design and persistent object modeling. With these new tools you can view and edit a visual model of your object-oriented code in C++, Objective-C, or Java, and use the model to navigate your source base. Then, create an object graph of your application's object model, and automatically generate a schema for Cocoa's new Persistence Framework.

Presenters:
- Chris Espinosa, Apple Developer Tools
- Miguel Sanchez-Sandoval, Apple Developer Tools

Demo: Stefan Reich, Apple Developer Tools

314.title: Compile and Link Strategies on Mac OS X
314.description:
From performance to accessing system technologies, Mach-O is the dynamic runtime of choice for all compiled code. Learn about Mach-O, including details of the dynamic linker, use of shared libraries, and static linking. Learn how choices in link options affect runtime performance. Prebinding and launch performance are covered, as well as details of advanced language usage.

Presenter:
- Matthew Formica, Cocoa & Developer Tools Evangelist
- Jeff Glasson, Manager, Linkers and Loaders
- Robert Nielsen, Software Engineer, Development Technologies
- Geoffrey Keating, Compiler Engineer

315.title: Debugging in Xcode
315.description:
This session examines the latest concepts, improvements, tips, and tricks for debugging in Xcode. Learn how to configure, run, and debug apps using source-level debugging within Xcode. Also learn about Xcode's powerful Fix and Continue feature, which allows you to make changes to a running app, and how to use the debugger's formatter to make your debugging experience even more productive.

Presenters:
- Christopher Friesen, Senior Xcode Engineer
- Jim Ingham, Senior Debugger Engineer
- Jason Molenda, GDB Programmer

317.title: Interface Builder: Techniques for the Advanced User
317.description:
This session on Interface Builder will cover advanced topics such as building and debugging Cocoa palettes, so that you can leverage Interface Builder more effectively.

Presenter: Chuck Fleming, Engineering Manager of the IB team
Demo: John Hess, Software Engineer

318.title: Using Xcode for Java Development
318.description:
This session showcases features that Xcode offers Java developers. Topics include: J2EE and JBoss, Ant integration, javac and/or jikes--which one to use and when, debugging with GDB and JDB, Applets, and application packaging. We highlight Xcode's ability to build JNI applications easily, and discuss how to use native Cocoa controls to build a great Aqua user interface for your Java application.

Presenters:
- Ted Jucevic, Java Engineer
- Dave Ewing, Xcode Engineer
- Greg Bolsinga, Serious Java Engineer

319.title: Programming for the Mac OS X 64-bit API
319.description:
Mac OS X Tiger adds support for 64-bit applications and will allow you to build solutions that can address massive amounts of memory. This session will specifically cover the 64-bit calling conventions, describe upcoming 64-bit capabilities and developer tools, and explain best practices for 64-bit programming and extending 32-bit application sources in Mac OS X.

Presenter:
- Wiley Hodges, Senior Product Line Manager
- Nick Kledzik, Sr. Software Engineer
- Stan Shebs, Sr. Software Engineer
- Matthew Formica, Cocoa and Developer Tools Evangelist

Demo: Jeff Glasson, Manager Core Tools

400.title: Java State of the Union
400.description:
The highly optimized and integrated implementation of J2SE in Mac OS X--along with support for essential technologies like Java3D and Java Advanced Imaging (JAI)--makes it the most compelling Java desktop development and deployment platform on the market today. Mac OS X Server v10.3 includes the popular JBoss application server, as well as Apache Tomcat.

Presenters:
- Scott Adler, Java Classes Tech Lead
- Alan Samuel, Java Technologies Evangelist

Demos:
- Caroline Clabaugh, Java Classes Engineer
- Jeff Norris, Mark Powell, Jet Propulsion Laboratory
- Ted Jucevic, Developer Technical Support
- Matt Drance, Developer Technical Support
- Axel Kratel, Senior Product Manager, Borland

401.title: Advanced Website Development Techniques
401.description:
This session is for webpage developers who want the latest information about developing highly interactive data-intensive web applications using XmlHttpRequest objects, LiveConnect, and forms with rich text content. Safari's support of these technologies provides web developers true separation of data and user interface.

Presenter: Maciej Stachowiak, Fungible Coding Unit
Demo: Kevin Decker

402.title: Understanding the Font APIs in Mac OS X
402.description:
This session outlines font technologies in Mac OS X and provides techniques that you can use to improve the way your application works with fonts. We discuss techniques for supporting font collections and the related font management advances in Carbon, Cocoa, and Font Book, and extensions to the printing architecture that provide additional flexibility in handling PDF and PostScript font data.

Presenters:
- Robin Mikawa, Manager, Type Engineering
- Nathan Taylor, Software Engineer, Type Engineering

403.title: Using Mac OS X Installer's Features to Deliver Your Application
403.description:
This session will teach you how to use the Mac OS X installer technology and introduce new top requested features. We explain how you can build an installer for your application, make your own installation packages, and personalize the installation experience using custom panes.

Presenters:
- Jean-Pierre Ciudad, Installation & Setup Group, Mac OS X Platform Experience
- Christopher Ryan, Installation & Setup Engineer
- Peter Bierman, Installation & Setup Engineer
- Jack Matthew, Installer Support Engineering

404.title: Fundamentals of Cocoa
404.description:
The object-oriented Cocoa application framework makes it easy to take advantage of Mac OS X's innovative technologies. This session provides fundamentals of the Cocoa framework and its primary language, Objective-C. We explain how to take advantage of common Cocoa programming paradigms such as target/action, delegation, bindings and the document architecture.

Presenter: Ali Ozer, Cocoa Frameworks

405.title: Understanding Document Binding on Mac OS X
405.description:
Uniform Type Identifiers (UTIs) are a new way of specifying document and data types. In this session, we cover how UTIs are used by Launch Services to enhance and simplify document binding. We also discuss new application information property list keys, as well as APIs for controlling document binding user preferences.

Presenter: Christopher Linn, Senior Software Engineer

406.title: Modern Networking Using CFNetwork
406.description:
CFNetwork is at the heart of the fast and reliable networking built into Mac OS X. This session is for those interested in accessing the network from within an application's normal event context without getting into the details of raw sockets or specific networking protocols. We cover CFNetwork's features, what's new, how and when to use CFNetwork, and how CFNetwork fits within Mac OS X.

Presenter: Becky Willrich, Technical Lead, CFNetwork

407.title: The Accelerate Framework
407.description:
The Accelerate Framework in Mac OS X is a powerful suite of platform-optimized libraries designed to provide high performance mathematical facilities such as LAPACK, BLAS, vMathLib, and image processing operations. This session discusses new advances and extensions to these libraries. The Accelerate Framework takes full advantage of G3, G4, and G5 processors to unlock best-of-class performance in your application.

Presenters:
- A. Sazegari, PhD Engineering Manager, Vector and Numerics Group
- Ian Ollmann, PhD, Vector and Numerics Group
- Robert Murley, Vector and Numerics Group
- Steve Peters, PhD, Vector and Numerics Group

408.title: Distinguish Your Application Through Excellent Design
408.description:
This session teaches the techniques and design methodologies to employ when designing for Mac OS X. We discuss techniques for designing your UI, including mental models and how they affect menu and window layout, how to approach common window layout scenarios, how to properly communicate status and feedback, common UI design practices to avoid, and more.

Presenter: John Geleynse, Manager, Software Technology Evangelism & User Experience Evangelist

409.title: What's New in Cocoa
409.description:
The Cocoa application framework continues to improve and evolve. This session explains some of the new features and APIs being planned for Cocoa, and offers suggestions on how they can be used in your applications. Topics to be covered include new advancements in controls, drawing and graphics, accessibility, document architecture, and more.

Presenter: Chris Parker, Cocoa Frameworks Engineer

411.title: Cocoa Tips and Tricks
411.description:
In this session, you'll discover strategies, shortcuts, and practical tips in Cocoa that can help you quickly solve a problem or add unique effects to your application. Learn about custom controls, advanced graphics techniques, cunning tricks, and more from the Cocoa experts at Apple. This is an intermediate-level session.

Presenters:
- Chuck Pisula, Cocoa Frameworks Engineer
- Tina Huang, Cocoa Frameworks Engineer
- Hansen Hsu, Cocoa Frameworks Engineer
- Doug Davidson, Cocoa Frameworks Engineer

412.title: Moving Applications to Unicode
412.description:
The Unicode-based APIs in Mac OS X are critical to producing a best-of-breed application and meeting customer expectations around the world. Find out how to move your Script Manager-based application to Unicode or create a brand-new Unicode application from the ground up. Learn about the importance of Unicode for the Japanese and Chinese markets, and discover what's new in Mac OS X international support.

Presenter: Deborah Goldsmith, International Engineer, Unicode Liaison
Demo: John H. Jenkins, Senior Software Engineer and Unicode Technical Director

413.title: Plug-in Development for Safari and Web Kit
413.description:
This session will cover best practices for Safari browser plug-in development and deployment, CFM versus Mach-O plug-ins, and techniques for everything from general plug-in development for Safari and Web Kit to advanced methods of integration with JavaScript.

Presenter: Chris Blumenberg, Safari/Web Kit Engineer

414.title: Taking Advantage of the New Web Kit Features
414.description:
Apple built the Safari web rendering engine using the APIs of Web Kit. You can do the same in your application. In this session, Carbon and Cocoa developers will learn how to use the Web Kit to add powerful HTML presentation, JavaScript processing, and accelerated Internet capabilities to their applications.

Presenter: Richard Williamson, Software Engineer

415.title: Introducing the .Mac SDK
415.description:
This session will examine the new .Mac Kit and how you can build applications with networked features to leverage .Mac's 24/7 service and over one half million paying members--all without any network programming. It will also cover the new .Mac-enhanced features in Tiger such as syncing to .Mac with SyncServices as well as the new dynamic DNS capabilities of Rendezvous.

Presenter: Scott Ryder, Group Manager, .Mac BaSE
Demo: Ryan Parks, Engineer, DotMac Kit

416.title: Using and Customizing Cocoa Bindings
416.description:
The Cocoa Bindings (the Controller Layer) introduced in Mac OS X Panther provides a new and easier way to manage user interfaces in Cocoa applications. View this session to learn about using and customizing bindings, and to see how this technology will evolve. This is an intermediate-level session.

Presenter: Ron Lue-Sang, Glue Code Architect

417.title: Easy and Powerful XML Processing with Cocoa
417.description:
From the operating system to file formats to the exchanging of data on the web, XML plays an increasingly important role wherever an open, cross-platform, scalable solution is needed. This session is for developers who are familiar with XML and want to learn about new Cocoa APIs in the Foundation framework.

Presenter: Sarah Wilkin, Software Engineer
Demo: Helena Ju, Final Cut Engineer

418.title: Introduction to Core Data
418.description:
This session provides an overview of the new Core Data framework in Cocoa. It will focus on the new functionality provided for managing and persisting model objects, which includes automatic undo/redo, input validation, and saving to various types of persistent stores (SQL and XML).

Presenter: Andreas Wendker, Sr. Manager, Core Data and WebObjects
Demos:
- James Dempsey, Operations Engineer
- Bill Bumgarner, Manager, Core Data

419.title: Best Practices in Website Development
419.description:
This best-practices session provides a comprehensive overview of Safari's Document Object Model, CSS, and JavaScript support. It will also include a discussion of common development pitfalls and techniques you can use to keep your content W3C-compliant and working across multiple browsers.

Presenter: David Hyatt, Safari Engineering

420.title: Building Your Website on Mac OS X
420.description:
Mac OS X is a great platform for prototyping, developing, and deploying your next Internet application. This session will cover in great detail the powerful technologies incorporated into the platform for website building. We cover PHP, mySQL, Tomcat, Apache, and additional open source favorites that are built in to every copy of Mac OS X, as well as others that you can readily install to create compelling websites.

Presenters:
- John Montbriand, DTS Engineer
- Daryl Lee, WebObjects Engineering

421.title: Replacing Old Style Windows and Dialogs with Nib Files
421.description:
This session will explain in great detail how to move your existing resource-based user interface to Nib files. We discuss how Interface Builder can be used to build a great Aqua user interface and go in-depth on how to modernize your Carbon code by switching to HIView, using the Carbon standard event handler, and using Carbon events to simplify your existing code.

Presenters:
- Curt Rothert, HIToolbox Lackey
- Bryan Prusha, Navigation Services Lackey

422.title: Switching to the Modern HIToolbox: HIView
422.description:
Whether you've been using the Toolbox for many years, or you're a new developer looking for a C/C++ widget set, this session is for you. After a short architectural overview, we explain through a set of examples how to adopt HIView and take advantage of other new HIToolbox features in your Carbon application.

Presenter: Guy Fullerton, Manager HIToolbox

423.title: Mac OS X Spoken Interface
423.description:
The Universal Access capabilities of Mac OS X are being enhanced with a spoken interface that provides a new way--through speech, audible cues, and keyboard navigation--to access the Macintosh. In this session, we provide details on these spoken interface extensions as well as a thorough overview of the Accessibility API.

Presenter: Eric Seymour, Manager, Spoken Interface Engineering
Demo: Aaron Haney, Software Quality Engineer, International and Text Group

424.title: Developing Accessible Applications
424.description:
This session covers best practices for ensuring Carbon or Cocoa applications work well with the Mac OS X Spoken Interface. Carbon developers will learn methods to easily add support for the Accessibility API into existing applications. Cocoa developers will take away techniques for adding accessibility support to custom controls.

Presenters:
- Mike Engber, Cocoa Group
- Guy Fullerton, Carbon Group

425.title: Modern Text Layout and Editing for Carbon Applications
425.description:
We discuss the API options for rendering, laying out, and editing text in your Carbon app helping you decide on the best approach. We discuss how to use the MLTE API for objects bound to an HITextView, work with monostyled text, chat text fields, and much more. Includes performance tips and tricks to optimize API usage.

Presenters:
- Giulia Pagallo, Manager, Text Input & Fonts
- Tom Madden, Text Processing Engineer

426.title: HTML Editing with Web Kit
426.description:
Learn all about the new HTML editing features available in Web Kit. This in-depth session will cover the new APIs and provide all the details you'll need to get started with this new technology.

Presenter: Ken Kocienda

427.title: Synchronizing Your Data with Sync Services
427.description:
This session builds on the Fundamentals of Data Synchronization session and will explain, using example code and demos, how to incorporate Sync Services in your application.

Presenters: Gordie Freedman/Nancy Craighill, Sync Services Development

428.title: Maximizing Java Virtual Machine Performance
428.description:
Improve your Java application's performance by choosing the right APIs and tuning the Java Virtual Machine to your needs. We focus on the performance capabilities of Java on Mac OS X and provide information about the latest APIs, garbage collection alternatives, and other under-the-hood optimizations available to you.

Presenters:
- Victor Hernandez and Roger Hoover, Java Virtual Machine
- Christy Warren, Tiger Responsiveness DRI

430.title: Advances in Cocoa Scripting
430.description:
Automation is an essential feature for any Mac OS X application and Cocoa includes powerful support for easily making your application scriptable. This session includes a brief overview of Cocoa scripting, and then presents detailed information about upcoming improvements, including improved error handling, improved text support, and adoption of the latest key-value coding features.

Presenter: Mark Piccirelli, Software Engineer, Cocoa Frameworks Group

431.title: Ten Steps to Building a Great Java Application on Mac OS X
431.description:
This session will discuss important considerations when bringing an existing Java application to Mac OS X. We cover user interface, file I/O, drag and drop, image performance, reflection techniques, and Mac OS X user experience enhancements that can be made to your Java application, without sacrificing portability or simplicity.

Presenter: Matt Drance, Java DTS

432.title: Fundamentals of Data Synchronization
432.description:
Learn about the new data synchronization services in Mac OS X. Sync Services make it easy to synchronize your application's data between computers, and with other applications. This session introduces fundamental concepts of synchronization and introduces the Sync Services architecture and API set so you can begin to incorporate synchronization into your applications.

Presenter: Toby Paterson, Sync Services Development

433.title: Modernizing Custom Controls to Use HIView
433.description:
If you have custom controls or custom content drawn with QuickDraw in your Carbon app, this session is for you. The Carbon HIView and other HIToolbox features allow you to easily support fully composited windows and improve the performance and responsiveness of your app. We show you how to implement HIViews to handle drawing, user interaction, accessibility, and lots more.

Presenters:
- David McLeod, Software Engineer, HIToolbox
- Curt Rothert, Personality Extra-ordinaire

434.title: Cocoa Performance Techniques
434.description:
Customers value application performance and responsiveness as highly as great new features. This session explains, through example code and demos, how to increase the performance of your application. We explore a variety of performance topics and techniques, such as view display optimization, and how to organize your data to help you develop fast Cocoa applications. This is an intermediate-level session.

Presenter: Troy Stephens, Application Frameworks Engineer

435.title: How to Thread Your Application with the MP APIs
435.description:
Learn how to leverage the threading architecture in Mac OS X with single and multiprocessor hardware to significantly boost the performance and responsiveness of your application. This session will discuss the threading models available in Mac OS X, show a step-by-step approach to threading, and use the Carbon multiprocessing APIs to thread a tight loop to gain a performance boost. Also discusses how to use semaphores to notify the main thread once computation is done.

Presenters: Xavier Legros, Mac OS X Technology Evangelist

436.title: Advanced Core Data Features
436.description:
Learn about the more advanced features of the new Core Data framework, including how to work with multiple persistent stores at the same time, how to use predefined fetch requests and predicates to find your objects, how to get more out of your validation rules, and how to manipulate schemas at runtime.

Presenters: Ben Trumbull, Melissa Turner, Persistent Software Engineers

437.title: Advanced Development with Cocoa Text
437.description:
Cocoa's powerful text system continues to evolve. View this session to learn advanced, in-depth coding techniques, including how to control the flow of text and how to incorporate compelling inline content into your text. This session will also discuss future advancements to the Cocoa text system.

Presenter: Douglas Davidson

438.title: Using the Spotlight Framework
438.description:
We discuss how to integrate with Spotlight to enhance the search user experience of your application on Mac OS X. Don't miss this opportunity to learn how to use the Spotlight APIs and write a Spotlight importer for your documents.

Presenter: Dominic Giampaolo, Spotlight Weenie

440.title: Dashboard Widget Development In-Depth
440.description:
Dashboard's power comes from its widgets, which users see and use when Dashboard is invoked. Developing a widget requires working with bundles, property lists, and a combination of HTML, CSS, and JavaScript. We walk you through the creation of sample widgets, discuss features that may be implemented in a widget, and touch on native code integration through a widget plug-in.

Presenters:
- Andy Grignon, Software Engineer
- John Louch, Software Engineer

500.title: USB in Mac OS X
500.description:
USB offers several benefits to users, such as low cost, expandability, auto-configuration, and hot plugging. Learn about the progress Apple has made with USB over the past year, including our adoption of USB 2.0 in all currently shipping products. We discuss where things are going in the future, what new device classes are on the horizon, and we outline the types of solutions possible with USB today.

Presenters:
- Craig Keithley, I/O Technology Evangelist
- Fernando Urbina, USB Software Team
- Rhoads Hollowell, USB Software Team
- Barry Twycross, USB Software Team

501.title: FireWire Overview
501.description:
FireWire is Apple's high-speed interface of choice for devices requiring high bandwidth, long cable distances, or a high-powered bus. Learn about the progress Apple has made over the past year with FireWire services, hardware, and tools. We discuss where things are going in the future, and outline the types of solutions possible with FireWire today.

Presenter: Eric Anderson, Manager, FireWire Software

502.title: Developing Bluetooth Applications
502.description:
Apple is leading the way in popularizing Bluetooth by making this wireless technology available on all Mac systems. This session will outline the variety of methods that applications can use to access Bluetooth devices. Topics will include how to detect when Bluetooth devices are present as well as best practices when using Bluetooth serial ports, headsets, cell phones, and HID devices.

Presenter: Eric Brown, Bluetooth Software Manager
Demo: Jason Giles, Bluetooth Software Engineer

503.title: Optimizing for the Power Mac G5
503.description:
The 64-bit G5 processor and high-bandwidth architecture make the Power Mac G5 a breakthrough in processing power. We focus on optimization for the G5: memory I/O, using the Velocity Engine, Mach-O, threading, loop unrolling, loop alignment, gcc G5-specific flags and other ways you can optimize your code for this powerful platform.

Presenters:
- Mark Tozer, Hardware Evangelist
- Sanjay Patel, G5 Performance Engineer
- Steve Hikida, Sr. Manager, Compiler Team, IBM
- Ron Price, Sr. Compiler Manager

504.title: Rendezvous Update
504.description:
This session is an overview of Rendezvous, Apple's implementation of the open protocol standard for zero configuration networking. We cover enhancements, new capabilities and platforms, and how to Rendezvous-enable applications and devices. We explain the APIs and how to use them, and discuss best practices for Rendezvous developers.

Presenters:
- Dr. Stuart Cheshire, Architect
- Kiren Sekar
- Roger Pantos

600.title: Enterprise IT State of the Union
600.description:
Apple continues to capture the attention of IT organizations as it increases its product offerings for the enterprise, providing flexible solutions that deliver on the promise of open standards. Learn from Apple executives and industry experts how Apple-based solutions deliver unparalleled ROI for customers looking to build the ultimate standards-based network infrastructure in a mixed client world.

Presenters:
- Bud Tribble, Vice President Software Technology
- Tim Hoechst, Senior Vice President, Technology, Oracle Corporation
- James Gosling, Vice President, Sun Corporation

601.title: HPC Technology Update
601.description:
Learn how Apple's high performance computing technology is being used to build powerful computational clusters with Xserve G5 and Xserve RAID. Hear how customers are designing and deploying large installations to solve a variety of complex computing problems. This session is a must for IT managers, project managers, and scientists who are building computational clusters.

Presenters:
- Douglas Brooks, Product Manager, Server Hardware
- John Thuotte, Business Development, Western Region Voltaire
- Dave Paulmark, XL Fortran Development, IBM Software Group Toronto Laboratory
- Benjamin Singer, Single Processing Scientist, Princeton
- Dr. John Medeiros, Senior Scientist, COLSA Corporation

602.title: Introducing Xsan
602.description:
Xsan is Apple's high-performance, easy-to-use SAN file system for Mac OS X and Mac OS X Server. Find out how Xsan can be deployed as a platform for workflow in demanding environments, as an affordable alternative for storage consolidation, and as centralized storage for a computational cluster. Learn how Xsan will create new opportunities for applications demanding high-speed access to shared data.

Presenter: Tom Goguen, Director Server and Storage Software

604.title: HPC System Design on Mac OS X
604.description:
Developers will gain an in-depth knowledge of hardware architectural issues including interconnect technologies, storage solutions, file systems, and software frameworks. Learn about new and emerging hardware architecture technologies including hardware interconnects, and we'll also cover topics such as available storage solutions, filesystems, and software frameworks.

Presenters:
- Skip Levens, Server Technology Manager, WWDR, Apple
- Dr. Srinidhi Varadarajan, Director, Terascale Computing Facility, Virginia Tech

605.title: Third-Party Enterprise Backup Solutions
605.description:
View this session to learn how to choose and use the best enterprise backup solution for your company. Solutions from BakBone, Dantz and other leading vendors are showcased for your specific backup needs. This session is intended for system administrators, IT managers, and developers.

Presenters:
- Chris Bledsoe, Sr. Enterprise Alliance Manager
- Pat Lee, Senior Product Manager, Dantz
- Tim Jones, Chief Technology Office, TOLIS Group
- Andrew Bowles, Director, Strategic Alliances, BakBone Software
- Randy Batterson, Director of Strategic Alliances, Atempo

606.title: Third-Party Collaboration Solutions
606.description:
Learn how your Mac clients can operate within a Domino, Exchange, or GroupWise environment. Become acquainted with enterprise-class solutions from Kerio, OpenText, and Stalker that allow you to run your collaboration infrastructure on Mac OS X Server and Xserve.

Presenter: JD Mankovsky, Consulting Engineer

607.title: Third Party Client Management Solutions
607.description:
Learn how your Mac clients can be managed by solutions from Altiris, LANDesk, and Marimba. Understand the options available from Apple, FileWave, Netopia, and Sassafras for deploying your client management infrastructure on Mac OS X Server and Xserve. System administrators and IT managers working within heterogeneous environments will find this session useful.

Presenter: John DeTroye, Senior Consulting Engineer

608.title: Database Solutions for Mac OS X
608.description:
Hear four case studies about application development on Mac OS X featuring these popular databases: 4th Dimension, FrontBase, FileMaker Pro, and OpenBase. By examining both in-house and commercial application development you'll see the unique offerings for Mac OS X each environment offers. See how our wealth of RDBMS tools can fulfill your development needs.

Presenter:
- Tyler Stone, Worldwide Developer Relations
- Alykhan Jetha, Marketcircle
- Chuck Sholdt, 4th Dimension
- Eric Jungemann, InfoMatrix
- Avi Drissman, Harris & Baseview

609.title: Learn to Develop with WebObjects
609.description:
Learn how WebObjects can help you write applications faster and more easily in this technical overview. Key aspects of the WebObjects architecture, its technical advantages, and its relevance to web application development are presented. Includes demonstrations of WebObjects tools, design and flow of a typical WebObjects application, and a review of deployment scenarios.

Presenter: Malcolm Crawford, Technical Publications

610.title: JBoss in Mac OS X Server
610.description:
In this session, you will get an overview of the JBoss server architecture. Learn how to deploy both WebObjects and J2EE applications using the tools that are provided with Mac OS X Server. This is an introductory to intermediate-level session.

Presenter: Ray Kiddy, WebObjects Engineering

611.title: File System Access Control Lists
611.description:
File System Access Control Lists (ACLs) allow fine-grained management and administration of file systems and workflows. In this session you will learn about Apple's File System ACL model, Open Directory integration for more scalable group management, and available developer APIs.

Presenters:
- Rusty Tucker, Mac OS X Server Engineering
- Mike Smith, Kernel Engineering, Core OS

613.title: Creating Application Clusters for Apache and MySQL
613.description:
Learn how to use fail-over and load-balancing technology from Emic Networks with Apache or MySQL applications running on Mac OS X. The Emic Application Cluster (EAC) includes performance scalability, load balancing, fault tolerance, and continuous availability with fast fail-over, as well as centralized cluster management--all running on Xserve technology.

Presenter: Thomas Loran, Principle System Engineer

614.title: Deploying Java Applications on Mac OS X
614.description:
Learn about the various Java-based deployment options available to you on Mac OS X. We also show how you can use Xcode to make a great Java Web Start application or Java applet, and how you can take advantage of Ant to simplify your building and deployment process.

Presenters:
- Karl Hsu, Java Runtime Engineer, Java Engineering
- Scott Kovatch, Java Runtime Engineer

615.title: Xsan In Depth
615.description:
Dig in and learn how your application can leverage the powerful collaborative and workgroup features in Xsan, Apple's high-performance, easy-to-use SAN file system. We discuss available APIs and give best practices and guidelines for integrating your application, utility, or workflow.

Presenter: Greg Vaughan, Core Server Architect
Demo: Mike Margolis, “demo monkey”

616.title: Inside Mac OS X Server
616.description:
Dig into the groundbreaking new features planned for Mac OS X Server, including the architecture and APIs available for developers. Each major feature covered will highlight the developer opportunities and integration points for your application or service.

Presenters:
- Kazu Yanagihara, Mac OS X Server Engineering
- Rusty Tucker, Mac OS X Server Engineering
- Chris Jalbert, Mac OS X Server Engineering

618.title: Distributed Computing Made Easy with Xgrid
618.description:
This session covers how scientists, animators, and developers can use Xgrid to distribute their applications. We describe the different protocols, developer APIs, and services provided by Xgrid, and provide guidelines for integration with MPI and other clustering solutions.

Presenters:
- David [KC]r{a,ee}mer, Xgrid Engineering
- Charles Parnot, Scientist/Biologist, Stanford University

620.title: Understanding Oracle 10g for Mac OS X
620.description:
View this session to learn about Oracle's latest grid-based relational database solution, Oracle 10g. Grid computing reduces the cost of IT by clustering servers together to function as a single large computer, shifting resources dynamically between applications. View this session if you are an in-house developer looking for a highly scalable and reliable database on Mac OS X Server.

Presenter: Thomas Kyte, Vice President, Core Technologies, Oracle Corporation

621.title: Understanding Sybase ASE for Mac OS X
621.description:
Sybase is opening up new opportunities for enterprises seeking cost-effective ways to build mission-critical applications. Sybase Adaptive Server Enterprise (ASE) 12.5 allows enterprise developers to create sophisticated applications for resolving business challenges. Learn to develop enterprise-caliber applications with Sybase ASE 12.5 on Mac OS X Server.

Presenters:
- Steve Olson, Technical Director, Server Engineering, Sybase
- Eric Leister, Software Engineering Manager
- Dr. Keith Campbell, Chief Information Officer, Inoveon Corporation
- Bob Cusick, Managing Director, Servoy USA

622.title: WebObjects Optimization, Security, and Scalability
622.description:
Learn about deploying WebObjects into real world situations. Topics include a tour of the tools available for determining where the bottlenecks are, configuration options for addressing scalability issues, and how to achieve scalability in a secure fashion. Load balancing, content aggregation, and other issues of deployment are also discussed.

Presenters: Bill Bumgarner, Max Muller

624.title: Safari in the Enterprise
624.description:
Learn how leading enterprise vendors such as SAP, Oracle and PeopleSoft develop and deploy client solutions on Mac OS X using Safari and other thin-client technologies. Macintosh system administrators responsible for SAP, Oracle and PeopleSoft, and in-house developers for thin clients should view this session.

Presenters:
- Mark Malone, Internet Partnership Manager
- Mark Cianca, Director, Academic Info Systems, University of California, Santa Cruz
- Jesper Andersen, Group Vice President and General Manager, Tools and Technology, PeopleSoft

625.title: Integrating Mac OS X with Heterogeneous Networks
625.description:
Learn how to easily integrate Mac OS X clients and servers into a heterogeneous network. Find out what it takes to integrate with UNIX and Windows networks; how to assume the duties of file and print server in an Active Directory domain; how to set up users' home directories on a Windows network served from an Xserve; and other system administration responsibilities.

Presenters:
JD Mankovsky & Eric Clements
Apple Consulting Manager & Directory Services Engineer

626.title: Xserve Deployment
626.description:
Learn how to deploy Mac OS X Server and Xserve in an enterprise network. Apple's internal IT organization will share best practices in deploying Apple server solutions in a heterogeneous network. This session is for system administrators deploying Mac OS X Server and Xserve.

Presenters:
- Douglas Brooks, Product Manager, Server Hardware
- Eric Senf, Systems Support Team Leader/Network Engineer, F+W Publications
- Richard Moon, Data Center Manager, Apple IS&T
Demo: Greg Smith, Consulting Manager, Apple Enterprise Services

627.title: Inside Directory Services
627.description:
Learn about the new directions and refinements planned for Apple's Open Directory architecture, LDAP directory services, Network Authentication Service Discovery, Network Service Location, the Open Directory API, and migration from NetInfo to Open Directory.

Presenter: David M. O’Rourke, Engineering Manager
Demo: Jason Townsend

628.title: Introduction to Eclipse
628.description:
Eclipse is a rapidly evolving open source project that includes a feature rich IDE for Java development. View this session to learn about the Eclipse platform, the new features and capabilities in Eclipse 3.0, and how you might use Eclipse for your next Java project on Mac OS X.

Presenters: John Wiegand, Erich Gamma, Eclipse Platform PMC

629.title: Using WebObjects EOF
629.description:
This session will provide you with an in-depth exploration of the intermediate and advanced features of the Enterprise Objects Framework (EOF) in WebObjects. Topics include performance optimization, shared editing contexts, raw rows, multi-threaded database access, and data synchronization and locking. This is an intermediate-level to advanced session.

Presenter: James Dempsey, Operations Engineer, Apple Software Customer Seeding

630.title: Network Administration Best Practices for Education
630.description:
Learn tips and tricks from the experts at the Higher Education Mac OS X Lab Deployment Initiative. Discover scripts and directory integration techniques for deploying labs in a higher-education environment. In this session, system and network administrators will receive useful sample roadmaps for deploying Mac OS X within their institutions.

Presenters:
- Richard Glaser, University of Utah
- Philip Rinehart, Yale University

631.title: Scripting for System Administrators
631.description:
Learn how to script common system administration activities using various methodologies for Mac OS X, such as bash, Perl, and AppleScript. This session is a great opportunity for the system administrator looking to use automation to simplify tasks.

Presenter: Joel Rennich, AFP548.com

632.title: Xsan Deployment for Video Workflow
632.description:
Xsan is an ideal platform for collaboration with Apple's industry leading professional video products. Learn about recommended Xsan deployment scenarios for various collaborative video editing environments directly from Apple engineers.

Presenter: Brett R. Halle, Director, Pro Video Applications Engineering

633.title: WebObjects Overview
633.description:
This session provides an overview and roadmap for WebObjects. Meet the key players and discover the exciting news that Apple has planned for WebObjects in the year ahead.

Presenter: Bob Fraser, Product Manager, Java and WebObjects

635.title: Security Best Practices Using Open Source Tools
635.description:
Learn how Mac OS X Server, plus open source tools, can help you protect your enterprise's network and provide enhanced security. Security experts from Apple's IT and Consulting teams discuss the security features built into Mac OS X Server, plus how to verify and improve your security model using tools such as Nmap, Netcat, Nessus, Snort and a variety of other open source tools.

Presenters: Brian Sathianathan, Damien Weiss

636.title: Porting Visual Basic Applications to Mac OS X
636.description:
Learn how to use REALbasic to port your existing Visual Basic application to the Mac OS X platform. See the differences between Visual Basic and REALbasic, and learn how to take advantage of this tool for migrating your applications to the Mac. Find out how far VB Project Converter will take you, and learn tips, tricks, and techniques that will help make your port go as smooth as possible.

Presenter: Hank Marquis, CTO, SlayFire Software Co.

637.title: Introduction to Sun Java Studio Creator
637.description:
Sun Java Studio Creator is a tool for Java application development designed to deliver Java to millions of developers via new technology, ease-of-development features and vastly improved developer productivity. Provided is an overview of the product, some principles of ease-of-development and a detailed walkthrough of its productivity features and capabilities.

Presenter: Robert Brewin, Distinguished Engineer, Corporate Developer Tools, Sun Microsystems
Demo: Carl Quinn, Sr. Staff Engineer, Sun Microsystems

638.title: Xserve RAID Best Practices
638.description:
View this session to learn how to combine Xserve RAID in configurations that meet demanding new storage needs with a high degree of reliability and redundancy. For example, we discuss best practices for building a remote data replication and disk-to-disk-to-tape workflows. This session is for network planners, IT project managers, and network administrators.

Presenters:
- Alex Grossman, Director Hardware Storage
- Ryan Klein, Business Alliance Manager, QLOGIC
- Stephen Terlizzi, Vice President Marketing and Business Development, Candera Inc.

639.title: How to Test and Debug Your Cross-Platform Java Application on Mac OS X
639.description:
In this session we show you critical techniques for building fully platform-independent Java applications that can be deployed effortlessly on Mac OS X and other OS platforms. We demonstrate tools for diagnosing and troubleshooting your Java application, and provide pointers to the resources that Apple provides the Java development community.

Presenters: Tom O’Brien, Barry Langdon-Lassagne, Java Product Engineering

640.title: Inside Network Authentication
640.description:
Mac OS X Server's robust authentication model is based on Kerberos, the industry standard network authentication protocol. This session discusses enhancements to the implementation of Kerberos both for the server and for end-user single sign-on. You will also learn how to ensure that your application is compatible across the different versions of Mac OS X Server and client using the Kerberos authentication protocol.

Presenters:
- Jason Townsend, Open Directory Engineering
- Leland Wallace, Senior Engineer, Core Servers

641.title: Integrating Apple Remote Desktop
641.description:
Apple Remote Desktop is a powerful desktop management solution for Mac OS X that blends software distribution, asset management, and remote assistance into one easy to use application. Get under the hood and learn how you can extend Apple Remote Desktop to streamline your desktop management processes at this informative session.

Presenter:
- Nader Nafissi, Server and Storage Software Product Manager
- Tony Graham, Systems Engineer
- Steve Hayman, Senior Consulting Engineer
- Mike Bombich, Senior Systems Engineer

642.title: HPC Software Performance Optimization In Depth
642.description:
This session provides an in depth look at Mac OS X technologies and applications for optimizing all aspects of software performance specific to a computational cluster. Information covers the OS services, job schedules, optimized libraries, cluster profiling tools, and third party cluster computing development frameworks like GridIron's XLR8.

Presenters:
- Warner Yuen, HPC Consulting Engineer
- Stephen C. Peters, Ph.D.
- Joshua Durham, Computer Systems Engineer, Virginia Tech
- Dr. Dean E. Dauger, President, Dauger Research, Inc.
- Steve Forde, President, GridIronTM Software

643.title: Apple in the Enterprise: Myths vs. Realities
643.description:
This session cuts through the hype and gives you the facts and data you need to make, or defend, an Apple hardware or software decision. Learn where Apple has enjoyed considerable success as an enterprise vendor and what has worked at other organizations. We also articulate the reasons why you should develop your next solution on a Mac.

Presenter: Brian Croll, Sr. Director, WW Software Product Marketing

644.title: Inside Apple Remote Desktop
644.description:
Apple Remote Desktop provides powerful desktop management, reporting and help-desk style remote control and assistance to make administering Mac OS X desktops or servers easier than ever. Learn how to get the most out of Apple Remote Desktop by viewing this informative session.

Presenter: Nader Nafissi, Server and Storage Software Product Manager
Demo: Michael Lopp, Senior Engineering Manager, Desktop Management Solutions

645.title: Mac OS X Server Update
645.description:
Mac OS X Server, Apple's industrial-strength operating system, is well known as a powerful and robust server platform thanks to its excellent support of industry standards and use of popular open source software projects. Find out all about the major new features coming in the next major release of Mac OS X Server.

Presenters:
- Eric Zelenka, Sr. Product Line Manager, Server and Storage Software
- Greg Burns, Sr. Director, Server and Storage Software Engineering
Demo: Eric Zelenka

646.title: Apple and Scientific Computing
646.description:
Whether it's the PowerBook G4 for UNIX to go, the Power Mac G5 for computational horsepower, or the power and scalability of Xserve G5 and Xserve RAID, Apple delivers an ideal platform for scientific computing with an exceptional price/performance ratio. Learn how Apple products are driving momentum in scientific markets and how science professionals are using Mac OS X to increase productivity.

Presenters:
- Bud Tribble, Vice President, Software Technology
- Elizabeth Kerr, Ph.D., Director, SciTech Market
- Chen Peng, Sr. Systems Engineer and HPC Architech, Temasek Life Science Laboratory, Singapore

647.title: Desktop Management Technologies
647.description:
In this session you'll learn about Apple's evolving desktop management strategy in increasingly complex and rapidly changing environments. You'll learn about the changes and updates to the tools that Apple provides to make managing user environments easier and more powerful than ever.

Presenter: Michael Lopp, Desktop Management Solutions

700.title: QuickTime and Digital Media State of the Union
700.description:
QuickTime powers the industry's best media tools including Apple's own suite of innovative applications, and the world's best content is being created and delivered with QuickTime. From workflow to delivery, QuickTime has you covered. This session discusses the latest industry trends and technology advances.

Presenters:
- Frank Casanova II, Senior Director, Product Marketing, Interactive Media Group
- Aimee Nugent, Product Line Manager, Core Media Technologies
- Mark Altekruse, Audio Marketing Manager, Professional Markets
- Dion Scoppettuolo, Product Marketing Manager, Professional Applications
- Joseph Linaschke, Technical Marketing Manager, Professional Applications

701.title: An Introduction to Digital Media
701.description:
The key to making great digital video is understanding how it works. Learn the building blocks of digital media with topics such as SD vs. HD, 3:2 pull-down, deinterlacing, and much more. If you are a beginner or someone who could use a refresher course, this is a must-see session.

Presenter: Hagé van Dijk, Senior Application Analyst, discreet

702.title: An Overview of QuickTime Codecs
702.description:
QuickTime supports dozens of codecs. This session presents a comprehensive overview of audio and video codecs, followed by an in-depth discussion of the codecs that come with QuickTime. Learn about the unique strengths of each codec, so you can determine which to use for your own particular needs.

Presenters:
- Dennis Backus, Senior Technical Marketing Manager
- Clifford VanMeter, Multimedia Producer/Author

703.title: The Encoding Process in Depth
703.description:
High-quality encoding is key to high-quality content. This session covers the entire compression workflow using QuickTime. Learn the tools, including Compressor, as well as the best practices for a variety of codecs, the techniques for automation, and how you can create a time- and cost-saving workflow that works for you.

Presenters:
- Dennis Backus, Senior Technical Marketing Manager
- Raúl Dejú, NINE systems

704.title: Preprocessing Principles
704.description:
Preprocessing is widely considered the key to making excellent video for digital delivery. This session teaches you the general principles for video preparation, including how to pick appropriate cropping, scaling, noise reduction, and image adjustment parameters for optimal quality.

Presenters:
- Dennis Backus, Sr. Technical Marketing Manager, QuickTime
- Ben Waggoner, Principal, Ben Waggoner Digital

705.title: QTVR: A Large-Scale Project
705.description:
What does it take to produce a large-scale VR installment? What kinds of decisions need to be made? What QuickTime tools can be used? How does one monetize the work? View this presentation and find out.

Presenter: Dennis Biela, Owner, LightSpeed Media

706.title: QuickTime in the Music Industry
706.description:
QuickTime on the web is an important component of the marketing of music and entertainment--as shown most dramatically by the phenomenal success of iTunes and the iTunes Music Store. Learn what works and does not work, from the labels, the artists, and the developers.

Presenters:
- Glenn Bulycz, QuickTime Product Marketing
- Dick Huey, Toolshed Incorporated
- Ken Wagner, Digital Strategist

707.title: QuickTime for the Web
707.description:
This information-packed session covers basic and advanced techniques for using QuickTime on your web pages. Topics include the easiest and most effective ways to embed QuickTime in a page, techniques that work cross-platform and cross-browser, how to use the EMBED and OBJECT tags, scripting the QuickTime plug-in and ActiveX controls with JavaScript, launching QuickTime from a text link, and much more.

Presenters:
- Rhonda Stratton, Director, QuickTime Product Marketing
- Steven Gulie, Sr. Tech Writer and Multimedia Web Monkey

708.title: Introduction to QuickTime Streaming
708.description:
With QuickTime Streaming Server, QTSS Publisher, and QuickTime Broadcaster, Apple provides a suite of world-class tools that make delivering your media easier than ever. This session guides you through setting up both a live and prerecorded streaming solution for delivery over the Web.

Presenters:
- Steven Tonna, Product Manager, QuickTime
- Victor Alexander, Software Seed Engineer

709.title: Deploying QuickTime Streaming Server
709.description:
For optimum streaming performance, QuickTime Streaming Server allows administrators to customize the deployment for any network condition. This session provides an in-depth look at deployment scenarios, including unicast vs. multicast, using relays, controlling access to streams, and much more.

Presenters:
- George Cook, Apple Consulting Engineer
- Laurence Kirchmeier, Merit Network Senior Engineer
- Patrick Bymhold, Apple Systems Engineer
- John Anderson, Apple Core Server Engineer

710.title: Content Production: Ask the Experts
710.description:
Bring your technical questions to this open Q and A session. A panel made up of Apple and industry experts addresses your QuickTime content development and workflow questions.

Panel:
- Ryan Lynch, QuickTime Product Marketing
- Eric Blanpied
- John Healey, Akamai Technologies
- Steve Gulie, Apple
- Mark Griffiths, Bluish, Ltd.
- Ben Waggoner, Ben Waggoner Digital
- Stephen Tonna, Apple Computer

711.title: Enhanced Learning with QuickTime
711.description:
QuickTime can help you create and deliver engaging instructional content. Learn how Brigham Young University uses QuickTime for authoring online lectures, captioning and indexing online video, and delivering rich educational media to a wide audience. Discover what QuickTime can do for you in your enterprise or educational institution.

Presenter: David Egbert, Senior Developer, BYU

712.title: Mobile Content Production
712.description:
Professional mobile content services are a viable business in the U.S. and abroad. View this session to learn tips and techniques for editing and encoding multimedia for mobile downloading or streaming, using a variety of tools available in today's market.

Presenter: Kay Johansson, CTO, Multimedia Product, Teleca (Formerly Popwire)

713.title: Mobile Content Delivery
713.description:
From video mail to advanced professional multimedia services, hear from industry leaders in telecommunications about how mobile data services are integrated, delivered, billed, and managed from the inside out.

Presenters:
- Benjamin Feinman, Senior Product Manager, QuickTime
- Eugene Sarmiento, Ericsson

714.title: Introduction to Final Cut Pro HD
714.description:
Final Cut Pro HD has created a paradigm shift in the worlds of video and film post-production. This session provides an overview of Final Cut Pro HD and provides a walk-through of the basics, such as editing, transitions, audio mixing, and titling. No video editing experience is necessary.

Presenter: Joseph Linaschke, Technical Marketing Manager

715.title: Advanced Final Cut Pro HD
715.description:
With over 300 new features included in Final Cut Pro HD, this session focuses on topics such as advanced effects and editing techniques, color keying, color correction, media management, and audio finishing. Also learn the tips, tricks, and timesaving secrets from the pros for complete proficiency.

Presenter: Joseph Linaschke, Technical Marketing Manager

716.title: QuickTime Sells
716.description:
The speakers in this session use QuickTime to deliver world-class advertising and marketing campaigns to sell brands and products. Learn about their business models and creative processes, and the tools these companies use.

Presenter: Glenn Bulycz, QuickTime Product Marketing

717.title: QuickTime Interactivity
717.description:
QuickTime is not just linear audio and video; it provides a robust architecture for interactive experiences. This session discusses all interactive media types in QuickTime and how to create them. We also present ideas on how to use them effectively in a relevant way.

Presenters:
- Rhonda Stratton, Director, QuickTime Product Marketing
- Alex Ogle, Partner and Interactive Designer, Tubatomic Studios

718.title: Media Event Production Case Study
718.description:
Learn techniques for planning and executing large-event media encoding from this inside look into the production of a large technical conference. From the daily use of media at the event to online distribution of conference sessions, this presentation features the latest in tools and equipment for large-scale media production.

Presenters:
- Aliza Hutchison, Product Marketing, QuickTime
- Gudrun Enger, Director for Communications, ACM SIGGRAPH
- David Bergevin, Director, Technical Operations, Soma Media Inc.

719.title: QuickTime Pro in Your Workflow
719.description:
QuickTime Pro makes a great complement to other applications in your content production workflow. This session explains how to use QuickTime Pro to fill in the gaps in your workflow, with topics such as preparing media for delivery, automation techniques, using QuickTime Pro with other applications, and much more.

Presenter: Francesco Schiavon, Digital Media Deployment

720.title: Mobile Experts: An Industry Overview
720.description:
What is the status of high-speed mobile networks, services, and handsets today throughout the world, and how does multimedia play a key role? How will these platforms evolve over the coming months and years? This session provides you with an overview of the latest in mobile technologies and user trends from expert analysts in telecommunications and media.

Presenters:
- Benjamin Feinman, Senior Product Manager, QuickTime
- David Brudnicki, Sr. Director—Strategic Technology Development, AT&T Wireless
- Eugene Sarmiento, Ericsson
- Gabriel Sidhom, Vice President, Business Development, France Telecom R&D

721.title: Mobile Success Stories: Ahead of the Pack
721.description:
Wondering how mobile multimedia can work for you? Gain inspiration and knowledge from the experience of leaders in mobile content creation and delivery as they offer their insight on the success of existing mobile businesses.

Presenters:
- Jean-Philippe FOURNIER, Bouygues Telecom—Dept. for New Technologies
- Pierre Barbeau, Sprint PCS

722.title: QuickTime and the Motion Picture Industry
722.description:
In this session, we reveal some of the phenomenal uses of QuickTime in the motion picture industry today. From creation to production, to marketing and consumption, media experts discuss specific examples of QuickTime's contribution to world-class media projects.

Presenters:
- Glenn Bulycz, QuickTime Product Marketing
- Anton Linecker, Technical Operations Supervisor, Technicolor Creative Services Hollywood
- Scott Simmons, Visual Effects Supervisor, LiveWire Productions

723.title: A Powerful Combination: AppleScript and QuickTime
723.description: By combining the automation capabilities of AppleScript with the power of QuickTime you can dramatically improve your video production process. This session provides in-depth information on how to use AppleScript to automate your workflow and scale your production process. You'll also learn to access new levels of QuickTime functionality using AppleScript Studio.

725.title: Internet Radio in Depth
725.description:
From live news feeds to the latest music releases, Internet radio has become one of the most effective ways to reach a worldwide audience right from your desktop. Learn all there is to know about the Internet radio business and how you can turn your Macintosh into a professional radio station.

Presenter: George Capalbo, VP Engineering, Backbone Networks Corporation

726.title: QuickTime Case Studies
726.description:
This session provides an exciting walk through several case studies of some of the most successful uses of QuickTime in the world. Whether you measure success in audience reach, sales, or social goals, these case studies will provide the insight and knowledge you need for your own current and future projects.

Presenters:
- Scott Wilcox, SXSW Inc
- Gary Woodcock, Unthinkable Research LLC

727.title: QuickTime in the Enterprise
727.description:
From training systems and corporate communications to distance learning--view this session to hear from the experts who have implemented systems in major universities and corporate environments. Case studies cover the opportunities, challenges, and successes, and should provide a wealth of information for your future work.

Presenters:
- Nate Caplin, Manager, Webcasting and Streaming Media
- Dave Schroeder, Systems Engineer, University of Wisconsin—Madison

728.title: DVD Authoring with DVD Studio Pro 3
728.description:
Learn how to create chapter and compression markers, alternate audio tracks, and alternate video angles in Final Cut Pro HD. Then take your project into DVD Studio Pro where you will learn about MPEG-2 compression, the creation of Dolby Digital audio tracks, how to add DVD-ROM material, and the requirements for creating graphics for broadcast.

Presenter: Brian Schmidt, Senior Product Manager, DVD Studio Pro

729.title: Audio Production Using Logic Pro
729.description:
This session provides an introduction to Logic 6, and details how you can create a customized environment that integrates with your own production studio. Learn the ins and outs of MIDI and audio recording, streamlined editing and arrangement techniques, and Logic's comprehensive array of DSP effects and software instruments.

Presenter: Phil Jackson, Audio Product Specialist

730.title: The Evolution of Standards
730.description:
